captions.text:
BRADY HARAN: Hi there,
everyone.

Today I want to talk to you
about perfect numbers.
No, not those perfect numbers.
We've done them already.

I want to talk to you about
the perfect numbers
of sports and games.

Now, probably the sport most
associated with the term
perfect game is baseball.

That's because a baseball
pitcher can
throw a perfect game.

Barring unusual circumstances,
that's 27 up, 27 down.

Retiring every batter without
any of them making it to base.

Seeing we're kind of talking
about strikes, 12 in a row is
the goal for 10 pin bowlers.

That's a score of 300
across 10 frames.

There are two extra balls
to satisfy the
quirky scoring system.

Now, my preferred sport
is cricket.

Now, a cricket bowler can bowl
a hat trick, but that's not
really, really special.

Cricket in perfection, in my
opinion, is for the batsman.

And the accomplishment
thereafter is
six 6's in an over.

It's only happened twice in
first class cricket, and twice
at international level.

In darts, it's a
9 dart finish.
501 points from just 9 throws.

Apparently, there are 3,944
different ways to accomplish

it, the majority requiring a
bullseye with the final throw,

although that's not always the
most common way to do it.

On the snooker table, a perfect
break is the much
sought after 147.

All 15 reds with a black,
then the 6 colors.

But although it is called a
maximum, higher breaks are
technically possible.

Athletics used to have the four
minute mile, but that's

long gone since Roger Bannister
broke that one.
What is it at the moment?

Probably the best one is
the 2 hour marathon.

Who's going to be the first
person to run that race in
less than 120 minutes?
Tennis has a golden set.

Six games in a row without
conceding a point.
That is 24 points in a row.

It's extremely rare, though
it did happen at
Wimbledon this year.

Golfing perfection, well, that's
as simple as it gets.
A hole in one.

Many professionals wait a
lifetime to hit one, although

former North Korean leader Kim
Jong Il once hit five in a
single round.
Well, allegedly.
It's not all about sport.

There are other games where
you can achieve numbery

perfection, and anyone who's
been watching my videos lately

will know I've become a little
bit obsessed with dice.

In the game of Yahtzee, if
you're using the bonus point

system, the miracle score
would be 1,575.

And I'm pretty sure that's never
happened, unless Kim
Jong Il played Yahtzee once.

The odds of being directly dealt
poker's ultimate hand, a
royal flush, is 649,713 to 1.
So how amazing was that?

The highest opening
move in a game of
Scrabble is this 128 pointer.

Or using another dictionary,
this 130 pointer.

The highest possible move in
general play, well, that's a

vexed question, and
it depends on what
dictionary you're using.

But if this hypothetical board
ever presented itself, you

could play this move
for 2044 points.

And I bet even Kim
Jong Il would be
impressed by that one.

So we'll leave it there for now,
but I know there's a lot

more games and sports
where we could talk
about perfect numbers.

Perhaps leave some ideas
underneath the video, we'll
make another video soon.

And finally, a short apology to
all those Red Sox fans out
there.

--Somehow continue to
find it amazing.

I haven't done 105
of these yet.

You can see some cool patterns
coming and going on the top.

People watching the video can
count along to make sure I've
done all 105.

comments.author: Will Tapley

comments.text:
+Justin Carner "A fielding error doesn't spoil a perfect game." Actually, 
it does, because by definition, a perfect game has NOBODY reach 1st base 
(all 27 batters were out). What you are referring to is a no-hitter (where 
errors and walks are allowed).
comments.author: jawnintendoSH

comments.text: +Justin Carner Ah, thank you.
comments.author: greg55666

comments.text:
A fielding error doesn't spoil a perfect game. So i suppose it 
is theoretically possible to throw a perfect game and still lose if you 
give up 2-4 errors in an inning. Imagine what the odds would be on that, 
that would be a site to behold. There have been pitchers who have thrown a 
no hitter and lost but thats not nearly the same thing

comments.text:
I once worked out the chance of being dealt a guaranteed 7 No Trump opening 
hand in Bridge... it's not an easy calculation, as there are several 
different combinations of cards that can fulfill it (from 4 each of AQK + 1 
J, to 4 aces + KQJ & 7 others from any one suit). Although I no longer have 
the actual odds, I remember it being incredibly unlikely.﻿

comments.text:
you have not accounted for relativity which is a kinda big deal when you 
are dealing with those speeds. in theory something going the speeds of 
light does not notice the passing of time. this means that (assuming i'm 
doing this right) if you were to travel at light speed (which is 
impossible) you would actually be exactly 0 seconds older when you finish. 
i'm not a professional so i might have made some mistakes, but i am sure 
that at these speeds some weird effects will happen.

comments.author: Saifullah Khan

comments.text:
Hmm, fair point... But traditionally, times are measured by a standard as 
an outside observer, not by the participants, and I would assume that 
despite time dialation and special relativity, the photon would still be 
travelling a distance? Otherwise, the speed would not be the speed of 
light, but zero? (as a huge disclaimer although I do have a very basic 
grasp on physics, I am not a phyicist, nor will I ever claim to be one. I 
just enjoy thought experiments.)
comments.author: SQUIZZLER24

comments.text:
But if you're moving at the speed of light don't we have to consider 
special relativity, time dilation, and length contraction? If you were a 
photon travelling at the speed of light, the track's length would contract 
to 0, your time would stop relative to an outside observer. So running the 
marathon would take you 0 seconds in your reference frame. So is this the 
perfect marathon?

comments.text:
(Contd.) Also, just because there is a footspeed record, does not 
necessarily mean that record is the fastest one can travel on foot. Having 
quickly read an article about some scientific studies at Stanford, it's 
suggested that the maximum speed a human could run 100m is approx. 9 
seconds. In light of this, yes, the speed of light is ridiculous; 
especially through a medium. But this was only meant to be a bit of a joke 
anyway and I didn't especially feel like working out all that business.
comments.author: SQUIZZLER24

comments.text:
Firstly, i'm not American. I'm Welsh. Second, yes I did forget to metion 
that. This would have to be a very special kind of marathon racing photons 
through a vaccuum, but the time for 26 miles still stands. Third, a 
marathon *is* actually 26 miles and 385 yards and I incorrectly assumed it 
was just 26 - so yes, with that in mind, a marathon is 42.195km (rounded to 
3 sf). You can have that one.

Bloody yanks and the imperial system, A marathon is 42.195Km and you never

human footspeed on record is 44.72 km/h so that equals a marathon in 56:38 
Animal = The fastest land animal (The cheetah) can reach 120 km/h so that 
equals a marathon in 21:06 However, this does not account for endurance or 
anything else

comments.author: Ishkikababa

comments.text:
Uhm... What? Where did I say it was the average speed of all marathon 
runners? The reason I say it would be a perfect run is because that is the 
fastest possible time in which you could theoretically run a marathon. 
You'd have to be a photon, but that is the fastest possible time in which 
26 miles can be travelled. The idea of a marathon is to run it in the 
fastest time possible, therefore, that is the marathon's "perfect game". As 
for the second part of your comment, right back at you.

comments.text:
Got me thinking, what would the "perfect" time be for a marathon? Well... 
26mi = 41.842944km = 41,842.944m C = 299,792,458m/s Time = Distance/Speed t 
= 41,842.944 / 299,792,458 So, a perfect time in which to run a marathon, 
would be; 0.00013957303seconds.
